body:
> Where is static vs. dynamic library generation under Cargo control
> documented, anyway?

I've been meaning to consolidate all of Cargo's documentation, but haven't
had the chance. It's here:
http://doc.crates.io/manifest.html#building-dynamic-or-static-libraries

OK. The relevant dependences are in the crate which uses "regex" (https://github.com/John-Nagle/rust-chrono)  which is the "chrono" package with some parsing functions added. The versions used are:

```
regex = "0.1.12"
regex_macros = "0.1.6"
```

Relevant .toml files of those versions:
    https://github.com/rust-lang/regex/blob/6c0f8aa82582441e9cb3813048ef9b098c026db0/regex_macros/Cargo.toml
    https://github.com/rust-lang/regex/blob/master/Cargo.toml

The relevant section of the regex_macros .toml file:

```
[lib]
name = "regex_macros"
plugin = true
```

The unusual things about the regex_macros crate are that it's a crate within a crate (it's a subtree of regex) and it's a plugin. Could either of those trigger use as a .so file?

Plugins are dynamic libraries (they're dynamically loaded into the compiler), they should not be needed at runtime at all. The correct way to load them is to use the `#[no_link]` attribute, it seems that chrono has this, so maybe something else is loading `regex_macros` as a plugin without `no_link`?

Yes as @huonw mentioned this looks like intended behavior, so I'm going to close this.

@John-Nagle do you have a `Cargo.lock` I could look at? I might be able to help out in tracking down which of your deps forgot the `#[no_link]` tag.

OK. So somewhere, something supposedly pulled in "regex_macros" without #[no_link]. I cannot find where. The program giving trouble is my "rss_client". It does not use the regex package directly, and never mentions it, but uses my version of "rust_chrono", which uses regex for date-parsing functions. 

I can't find any place outside chrono that mentions regex at all. Nor is there a "macro_reexport" which would push the macros another level outward. I may be doing something wrong, but if so, it's probably something that isn't in the manual.

Miscellaneous fact: I have Rust installed in ~/local, not installed as root. Ubuntu 14.04.

Also, "cargo test" works fine, presumably because Cargo sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to include the "target/deps" directory.

Here's the rss_client tomo.lock file: 

`````` [root]
name = "rss_client"
version = "0.0.1"
dependencies = [
 "RustyXML 0.0.1 (git+https://github.com/Florob/RustyXML)",
 "chrono 0.1.15 (git+https://github.com/John-Nagle/rust-chrono)",
 "hyper 0.1.9 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]

[[package]]
name = "RustyXML"
version = "0.0.1"
source = "git+https://github.com/Florob/RustyXML#2072b4687faf659e018e7d3ee2d9e1eff5b345f8"

[[package]]
name = "chrono"
version = "0.1.15"
source = "git+https://github.com/John-Nagle/rust-chrono#a8c866d1ea08a2e5613bd5811f146b7c2e5cf987"
dependencies = [
 "regex 0.1.12 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
 "regex_macros 0.1.6 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
 "time 0.1.15 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]

[[package]]

]

dependencies = [

 "log 0.2.1 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
 "mime 0.0.7 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
 "mucell 0.1.12 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",

]

[[package]]

[[package]]

version = "0.1.12"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"

[[package]]
name = "regex_macros"
version = "0.1.6"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
dependencies = [
 "regex 0.1.12 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]

[[package]]
name = "rustc-serialize"
version = "0.2.10"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"

[[package]]
name = "time"
version = "0.1.15"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
dependencies = [

 "libc 0.1.1 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]

[[package]]
name = "unicase"
version = "0.0.3"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"

[[package]]
name = "unsafe-any"
version = "0.2.2"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"

[[package]]
name = "url"
version = "0.2.17"
source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
dependencies = [
 "matches 0.1.2 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
 "rustc-serialize 0.2.10 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)",
]```

``````

It looks like you may be accidentally [linking to `regex_macros` twice](https://github.com/John-Nagle/rust-chrono/blob/master/src/parse.rs#L1). The first one has `#[plugin]` and `#[no_link]`, but the second one does not.

Ah you already have the necessary lines [in `src/lib.rs`](https://github.com/John-Nagle/rust-chrono/blob/master/src/lib.rs#L195-L197) so they just don't need to be duplicated in `src/parse.rs`. I don't think you'll even need to import `regex_macros` in `src/parse.rs` to get the macros to work.

Note that the attributes in the documentation (`#[plugin] #[no_link]`) are crucial to get it to work. Also note that this is one of many reasons why plugins are currently unstable :)

> There's a .toml file under another .toml file.

This is actually a feature of Cargo where one repository can host many crates by having a separate directory for each crate.

Ah. That's it. I removed the imports in src/parse.rs, the dependency on the .so file disappeared from the final executable, and the program runs correctly. Thanks.

The compiler probably should detect such attribute inconsistencies across files. This sort of thing is likely to creep in as programs are refactored. That's how I got into this; the date/time parsing module was originally part of the RSS reader, and then I moved it to "chrono" with the rest of the date/time functions.
